div.l: The deuyll made a reue for to preche
Or of a sowter a shypman or a leche
¶ Say forth thy tale and tary not the tyme
Lo depford and it is half way to pryme
Lo grenewych that many a shrewe is inne
It were all tyme thy tale to begynne
¶ Now syres quod this oswolde the reue
I praye you all that ye you not greue
Though þᵗat I answere ⁊and somdele set hishouue
For lefull is wyth force / force of shoue
¶ This dronken myllar hath tolde vs heer
How that begyled was a carpentere
Perauenture in scorn for that I am one
And by your leue I shall hym quyte anone
Ryght in his churlys termes woll I speke
I praye to god his necke mow to breke
He can well in myn eye se a stalke
But in his owe he can not se a balke
AT trompynton not fer fro cambryge
Ther goth a broke ⁊and ouer that a bryge
Vpōn þᵉ whiche broke ther stont a mylle
And this is very soth that I you telle
A myllar was there dwellynge many a daye
As ony pecok he was proude and gaye
Pype he cowde and fysshe and nettes bete
And torne cuppes and well wrastyll and shete
Ay by his belt he bare a longe pauade
And of a swerde full trenchant was the blade
A Ioly popper bare he in his powche
Ther was noman for peryll durste hȳm towche
A sheffelde thwytell bare he in his hose
Round was his face ⁊and camoysed was his nose
Also pylled as an ape was his skulle
He was a market beter at the full
Ther durste no wyght honde vp on hym ledge
That he ne swore anon he sholde abedge
A thef he was forsothe of corn and mele
And that a slygh and vsant for to stele
His name was y hote deynus symkyn
A wyf he hadde y comen of noble kyn
